Award.AwardTitle: Build and Broaden: Collaborative Research: African American Family Relationship Research through Partnerships with HBCUs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports a conference that fosters connections and builds research collaborations between Historically Black Colleges/Universities (HBCUs), Minority-Serving institutions (MSIs), and research-intensive institutions (R1s). The proposal responds to NSFâ€™s Dear Colleague Letter, Build and Broaden: Enabling New Social, Behavioral and Economic Science Collaborations with Minority-Serving Institutions (MSIs). The goal of the Build and Broaden program, and this workshop, is to foster connections that enable the submission of competitive collaborative research proposals. The resulting projects would support research activity and funding at both an HBCU/MSI and an R1 institution, providing valuable research experiences and lasting research infrastructure investment at both institutions. The conference includes invited faculty mentors who are developmental science scholars committed to working with families from underrepresented groups, using diverse methodologies, and using within-group research designs to study the roots of intimate/marital relationships. These senior, tenured scholars have strong records of securing external funding to support their research programs and have demonstrated the ability to effectively mentor and collaborate with other researchers. Faculty mentors will present their research and provide the scaffolding needed for individuals who are less knowledgeable about relevant programs at NSF and the research funding process in general. Faculty mentors will meet with scholars appointed at HBCUs/MSIs and exchange ideas. <br/><br/>An evaluation survey will be conducted with all participants to assess the quality of the meeting, its impact on attendees, and the initial success at producing new collaborative partnerships. Follow up surveys will be used to assess how successful the meeting was at producing collaborative grant proposals that would not otherwise have been submitted. Understanding the developmental implications of interpersonal family function is important to many researchers, educators, practitioners, and policy makers. The proposed meeting seeks to enhance the breadth of talent and perspectives engaged in the research process, and in so doing to make new discoveries in this area.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Information about the Meeting

 
This virtual conference fostered connections and built research collaborations between Historically BlackColleges/Universities (HBCUs), Minority- Serving Institutions (MSIs), and research-intensive institutions(R1s). This virtual conference responded to NSF?s Dear Colleague Letter,
Build and Broaden: Enabling NewSocial, Behavioral and Economic Science Collaborations with Minority-Serving Institutions (MSIs).
The goalof the Build and Broaden program, and this virtual conference, was to foster connections that enable thesubmission of competitive collaborative research proposals. This virtual conference included identifying andfaculty mentors/scholars who are committed to working with families from underrepresented groups, usingdiverse methodologies, and adopting within-group research designs to study the roots of intimate/maritalrelationships. These senior, tenured scholars have strong records of securing external funding to supporttheir research programs and have demonstrated the ability to effectively mentor and collaborate with otherresearchers. Faculty mentors presented their research and provided the scaffolding needed for individualswho are less knowledgeable about relevant programs at NSF and the research funding process in general.Faculty mentors met with scholars appointed at HBCUs/MSIs and exchanged ideas. Mentees sent researchproject summaries to the conference organizers who then distributed the summaries to the mentors forreview. Time was allotted for mentors to meet with the scholars and provide feedback on their researchprojects.

 

HIGHLIGHTS OF THE PROGRAM

 
DAY 1 and DAY 2: A Pre-Conference took place over the first two days of the conference. A facilitator fromGrant Central presented the practical and conceptual aspects that are important to writing successful NSF proposals. The title of the presentation was Writing Winning Proposals. Mentees were required to attend thePre-Conference.


DAY 3
Introductions of conference hosts and mentors, and goals of the conference.
Dr. Chalandra M. Bryant (University of Minnesota),
Overview of Grant that Led to Conference
Dr. Tera R. Jordan (Iowa State University),
Pre-Conference Summary and Overview of Main Conference
Dr. Jennifer J. Ross (Tuskegee University), Introduction of Mentors


Presentations

 
Dr. Norma Burgess: The Role Mentors Play In Our Academic Lives and the Importance of Having MultipleMentors


Dr. Chalandra M. Bryant: Overview of the National Science Foundation and the Directorate for Social,Behavioral and Economic Science


Dr. Jennifer J. Ross, Dr. Tera R. Jordan: What Do We Mean by Developmental Sciences?


Break-Out Rooms:
Speed mentoring - Each of the mentors had six minutes to discuss
grantsmithing skillsand tips with mentees.


Dr. M. Belinda Tucker, Dr. Claudia Mitchell-Kernan: The impetus for their book titled, The Decline in Marriage Among African Americans, which set the stage a strength-based approaches to the study of AfricanAmerican
families and couples.


Dr. Armon Perry: The Development of African American Men?s Perspectives on Marriage and Fatherhood

Dr. Jeffery Shears: Values that Fathers Communicate to Sons? about Relationships/Marriage: Direct andIndirect Influences on Development

Dr. Tera Jordan: Questions and Wrap-Up

 

DAY 4
Dr. Jennifer Ross: Welcome Back, Overview of the Afternoon


Dr. Ming Cui: Romantic Relationship Development from Adolescence to Adulthood


Dr. Frank Fincham: Positive Approaches to Optimal Relationship Development


Break-Out Room Discussions:
What observations you have made about relationship/family and/ordevelopmental science research? What questions do you still have? How does your research reflectdevelopmental science?
 

Dr. Michael Cunningham: Developmental Precursors of Bravado Attitudes in African American MaleAdolescents


DAY 5
 

Dr. Chalandra Bryant: Welcome Back, Overview of the Afternoon


Break-Out Rooms: Mentees receive feedback on their research summaries.

Dr. Michael Young: Linking Your Project and Your Budget *Now that you have received feedback on yoursummaries, think about what it will take to launch and support your work.


Break-Out Room Discussions: Continuation of DAY 4's discussions

Closing Remarks

Dr. Bryant: Reminder of Grant that Led to Conference
 

Dr. Ross: Pre-Conference & Main Conference Meeting of Goals of Grant


Dr. Jordan: Recognition of Mentors, Final words
